intro: Aquilegia vulgaris var. fragrans, commonly known as the garden sorrel or sweet columbine, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its distinctive spurred petals and vibrant, often bi-colored flowers that range from red to purple. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained soil in full sun to partial shade. Its foliage consists of deeply lobed leaves, and it produces edible flowers and seeds that are used in culinary and medicinal applications. The fragrant scent of its blooms makes it a popular choice for gardens and floral arrangements.
